[Applause]
I have I don't know if I need to say
it's a cool job but it is a really cool
job but what I what I would like you
know especially for our young people to
realize is that you need to this to
figure out or you need to figure it out
but but dream at least about what you're
passionate about and if it's involved
with math and science or engineering
like it was for me and the other people
that have spoken to you today then you
should pursue it and it might not be
easy because learning math and science
in school was very difficult for me and
wasn't always smooth but decide what it
is that you like and don't give up while
you're on that journey so those are some
of the things I'm going to try to show
to you from my experiences through a
couple pictures I'm gonna show you this
is this is actually Buzz Aldrin a
picture was taken by me alarm strong so
I was six years old when I watched this
happen on my TV set and that's what
inspired me I said that's how do I do
that I want I'd had no idea I was gonna
happen
I was like that's the job I want and so
I went through high school and enjoyed
math and science and found out that
engineering might be something I'd be
interested in studying cuz it was kind
of like the applications of math and
science I got lucky enough to go to
Columbia University worked for a couple
years as an engineer after graduating
and then I started thinking about what I
really wanted to do with my life at that
point and it was the space program that
kept coming up in the back of my mind so
I went to grad school got very lucky I
had a chance to go to MIT and started
pursuing my application to be an
astronaut once I was in graduate school
so I sent my application to NASA and you
know what they told me they told me no
so I had to wait a couple years and I
applied again but then after a couple
years I got my PhD from MIT write big
deal so I put my new application and
guess what they told me that they told
me no so then so then I fact actually
went down in my ranking and the fit was
a lot of good that did me right so so a
couple years are going by and then
I moved to this to Houston this is the
Johnson Space Center this is where
astronauts train but to me this was the
place I wanted to be if I couldn't be an
astronaut I wanted to be working here
helping people go to space so I got to
know a lot of the astronauts I worked
for a contractor at the Johnson Space
Center I put in another application I
got an interview so they got to know me
very well is only only about a hundred
people get an interview they got to know
me real well and guess what they told me
after that they told me no so anyway I
applied again when I was in Atlanta and
got another interview and this time they
told me yes so after my fourth try I got
to thank you that was uh that was in
1996 so I tell you that story because
things don't always work out the first
time okay and and science scientists can
tell you this too the first time they
tried something in the laboratory or
they try and experiment it might not
work and for me just about nothing works
the first time I try it and I think that
that's okay I think the important thing
is that you don't give up okay so that's
why I tell you that story it's not to
give up if you're trying to pursue
something particularly for trying to
pursue a dream that isn't so easy
you gotta recognize hey this is not
maybe so easy I might have to tough it
out and that's that's what I did and I
got lucky and I'm on the second roll
from the top third from the left
so that was me back in 1996 now the cool
part of my job so I'm gonna talk a
little about flying in space but we do a
lot of cool stuff while we're on earth
and one of them I Miceli just a couple
of them there's lots of stuff but one of
them for me was getting to fly in a t-38
aircraft I was a private pilot but I'd
never been in a military airplane before
especially one like this which is really
cool to fly in this is a picture of me
in the in the cockpit and thank you so
this was taken as a National Geographic
documentary and they had these GoPro
cameras about once a week I got to do a
training flight and when I was looking
at this photo when I first got it I was
saying what what am I cuz I was leaving
my visor like see below me is like blue
like the sky and above me you see the
reflection my home it is like looks like
land and a
cloud deck so really what I figured out
is I was like this I think we were at
the top of a loop at about 24,000 feet
going about 500 knots upside down is
this a cool job or what all right I want
to talk a little about space walking and
and then I'll show you some stuff in
space I'm going to do a demo here this
is me working with some astronaut gloves
on and a power tool that we helped
design to do a job to repair an
instrument on the Hubble Space Telescope
there were 117 small screws that needed
to be removed from this instrument so we
practice things like this over and over
again it's a big team effort we have
instructors we have tool designers we
would practice this stuff on land and
then we'd go in the water and practice
the whole spacewalk or my missions we
had five spacewalks which is a lot of
space walking we did those five days ago
we had two teams we would alternate so
we would run those spacewalk scenarios
Monday to Friday in the pool just like
we would in space and those days were
great you know it's when we say boy I
can't wait till I get back tomorrow
that's how much fun it was doing this
stuff right now what's going on it's
it's kind of brightening the polat's me
on the left my good bueno my buddy is on
the robot arm on the right these scuba
divers are holding a big silver thing
it's a camera it's an IMAX camera they
made an IMAX camera automatic filling
our flight and they use some of the
footage that they took that day in the
pool to make that movie but that's us
practicing fixing the Hubble here's my
crewman talk a little about my my second
flight into space we're doing a training
exercise in an armored personnel carrier
down it's a emergency thing we were
doing down at the Kennedy Space Center
we launched you go from zero to 17,500
miles an hour in eight and a half
minutes it's a lot of power its
acceleration speed it is a really cool
ride into space that you take we got to
the Hubble a few days later we
rendezvous with it
grabbed it with the robot arm and then
we got the spacewalk and so there's a
picture of me space walking handling a
solar right so you work with really cool
tools you're inside of your own
spaceship which is your your spacesuit
and just over your shoulder at any
minute is the most beautiful scene
you've ever seen
seeing the the Earth from space at the
Hubble altitude you can see the
curvature of the earth
it takes up your whole field of view but
it's it's just magnificent this is a
picture of us going from darkness into
sunlight since we're going so fast in
space we get 45 minutes of Sun followed
by 45 minutes of darkness 90 minutes for
one lap you get 16 sunrises 16 sunsets
in one day and you can see the line as
you when you're spacewalking one thing
you can do is when you can kind of feel
the heat of the Sun coming take a look
at the planet you can see the Sun out in
the distance as are our stars out there
and what you realize is that date that
date line that difference between
blackness and light is moving and that's
that's the sunrise on earth that you're
watching and what you what hit me was
was that it's I'm watching the
revolution of our planet I'm watching up
the planet move you know you really
think of the Sun is coming up and going
down that's not what's happened that
sounds that moving I've seen it
Suns staying right where it is we're the
ones that are moving so that's me at the
end of spatial so I think we're going to
I'm going to do we've talked a little
about training and what we do in space
I'm gonna bring my friend out he's all
dressed up sorry man alright
okay so we got this wire coming that we
actually do this sort of stuff I showed
you the pool right remember the big
picture so the pool is really big it's
200 feet long 100 feet wide 40 feet deep
we get to get in our spacesuits and
practice our crew coordination all that
and but you're kind of slowed down by
the viscosity of the water it's not
exactly like moving in space so they do
this kind of stuff to us you're doing
all right man all right if you have any
trouble let me know so what they do is
they do hang us from wires like this
like Peter Pan because this gives us a
little bit of a different experience if
you were to push off its for me right
there you go he goes flying you don't
want that to happen when you're in space
so you learn how to keep yourself stable
and do your work so one thing we would
do is perhaps I'm gonna grab your feet
okay so you always want if your feet are
nice and stable then you're gonna stay
in one place and you can do your work so
go ahead me want that let me give you
this okay keep it out of my face little
bit there we go all right here we go
all right he's got a helmet on I don't I
can get hit with everything so so he's
not doing something that's very easy
it's harder for a couple reasons one is
is that he's not as stable as he'd like
to be I've got his feet but he's
floating and all this stuff is floating
if he were doing this in space he'd have
this stuff attached to a tether so he
drops this it's gonna go to the floor he
got it in there congratulations you
wanna try this other one all right
okay see that's what happens with
gravity they tried it again man we'll
keep working so in space you would want
to have that on a tether so when it
float away from you and he's also
working with gloves on so I described
spacewalking working on the Hubble is
like working on your car except you're
doing it with boxing gloves on so you
have to design the tools a certain way
so that they're easy to use you don't
want to lose anything so you need
tethers and need hooks and things you
won't lose your stuff you got to keep
track of everything and be very very
particular of how you work he's got a
suit on which is also not the easiest
thing to work inside of our spacesuits
give us some extra pressure you have to
fight against that pressure to do your
job but he's got it this time I think so
we're gonna call victory so I'm gonna
leave you alone now so you can enjoy the
rest of your day but I would like
especially young people here to remember
a couple things one is is that whatever
it is that you might want to do I would
encourage you to pursue it with all your
heart you have to be true to yourself it
may not be the easiest thing to do but
if it's what you want to do you got to
give it a shot
so I want you to dream about what you
want to do I want you to think big aim
high you know if you're interested in
being an astronaut try to be an
astronaut if it doesn't work out you can
do something else but I would aim high
don't settle for second best do as well
as you can and the third thing is never
surrender okay
don't give up don't give up your dream
have a great day
[Applause]
